name: John the Ripper - Password Cracker.pdf
comment: John the Ripper is a powerful tool for identifying and cracking password hashes. Here, I first showed how to detect hash types, perform dictionary and brute-force attacks, and cracks protected ZIP files and NTLM hashes. This can be done using wordlists, rules, and incremental modes, we can efficiently tests password security.

name: Cain and Abel.pdf
comment: I installed Cain and Abel and explored its password-cracking capabilities. I tested cracking different hashes, including MD5, SHA-1, and NTLM. Additionally, I demonstrated both dictionary and brute-force attacks to recover passwords, showcasing the tool's effectiveness in ethical hacking and password security analysis.

name: Introduction to Hashcat.pdf
comment: I Used Hashcat to explore various attacks, focusing on password recovery through dictionary, brute-force, and other techniques. Analyzed cracking statistics, kernel performance, and candidate generation. I also demonstrated password cracking while interpreting Hashcatâ€™s output metrics, session details, and recovery status.
